G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000, and it is appropriately filed in the Lowell District Court, as the incident occurred within Middlesex County.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 166 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: As the occupier and manager of the premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful invitee, a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to avoid exposing invitees to unnecessary risk of harm, and to warn of any hazardous conditions that were known or should have been known to Defendant.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty of one who controls business premises toward patrons: to use due care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers not likely to be known to them but known or reasonably knowable to the defendant. That description matches the proposition about the occupier’s duty to a lawful invitee to maintain reasonably safe conditions, avoid unnecessary risks of harm, and warn of known or reasonably discoverable hazards.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: As the occupier and manager of the premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a lawful invitee, a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to avoid exposing invitees to unnecessary risk of harm, and to warn of any hazardous conditions that were known or should have been known to Defendant.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of common-law classifications of entrants (invitee, licensee, trespasser) in premises liability, and criticizing continued reliance on these categories. It does not recite or endorse the traditional invitee-specific duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of known or reasonably knowable hazards. Although the majority opinion in Mounsey does address occupier duties, the quoted concurring passage itself does not clearly support the specific invitee-duty formulation stated in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: a. Permitting heavy merchandise to be stacked dangerously high without adequate safety measures such as straps, barriers, or guardrails, contrary to reasonable safety practices.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is about premises liability for slip-and-fall injuries on snow and ice in a parking lot and the abolition of the natural vs. unnatural accumulation rule. It does not address stacking of heavy merchandise, use of straps or guardrails, or any analogous merchandising or storage-safety practices. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition concerning dangerously high stacking of heavy merchandise without safety measures.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 841-42 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: b. Failing to inspect or correct the hazardous condition of the shelves, which posed a foreseeable risk of falling objects injuring customers.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt concerns a concurring opinion about a gas station’s duty (or lack thereof) to warn customers of the obvious risk of injury from negligent operation of other vehicles. It does not address inspection or correction of hazardous shelf conditions or falling objects, nor any analogous premises liability duty regarding shelves. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition about failing to inspect or correct hazardous shelving conditions.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger."

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 786 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.proposition: c. Neglecting to implement precautionary measures or post warnings regarding the risk of falling merchandise, despite knowledge or constructive knowledge of similar risks.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts the mode-of-operation doctrine and states that where the store’s chosen mode of self-service makes dangerous conditions reasonably foreseeable, the owner is liable only if it failed to take reasonable precautions to protect customers. That necessarily encompasses the duty to implement precautionary measures or warnings about foreseeable risks (such as falling or spilled merchandise) once the owner has actual or constructive knowledge of those risks. The court frames the key factual question as whether the owner took adequate steps to forestall foreseeable injuries stemming from its mode of operation.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermkts., Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Courts adopting this [mode of operation] approach have concluded that where an owner’s chosen mode of operation makes it reasonably foreseeable that a dangerous condition will occur, a store owner could be held liable for injuries to an invitee if the plaintiff proves that the store owner failed to take all reasonable precautions necessary to protect invitees from these foreseeable dangerous conditions… [A] store owner will be liable… only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur… and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 56-57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, including her concussion and shoulder strain, along with attendant damages related to medical expenses, lost wages, and diminished quality of life.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent expressly rejecting that the defendants’ negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The judge concludes the evidence was insufficient on causation and that verdicts should have been directed for defendants, which is the opposite of the claimed proposition that defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused plaintiff’s injuries and related damages. Thus, this citation does not support the stated causation proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”
